Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2014 03:42PM Piano-girl wrote: Swimmom2:  I had to laugh at your circling the bed...I walk into my bedroom every night longing to be able to sleep like I used to - then I turn right around and head to the corner of my sectional couch.   I am about 5 and a half weeks out from BMX and I am absolutely surprised by my pain.  The horrible zingers that occurred at about week 2 and 3 are gone thankfully, but have been replaced by an odd sunburned feeling all over.  Every once in a while, I feel my chest area is "wet" during the day when it is not!  I am not on pain pills and didn't find they helped much anyway.  I try to massage the area as much as possible hoping this will help...

I have never heard anyone else say this.  I understand they will be flatter and wider, but really?  I am shooting for 350cc.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2013 04:52PM Piano-girl wrote: Just took my last "pre-surgery" shower (was told I couldn't take one in the morning) - today has been stressful, but it helps to have this community. My surgeon ordered me 2 mastectomy camisoles (lovely things complete with drain pockets) and 2 post surgical bras…I guess I will bring the camisoles to the hospital? Looking forward to being done with this whole thing!! Thanks for all the support.
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2013 12:49PM Piano-girl wrote: Hi girls...I'm back! Surgery went well - went in Tuesday, home on Friday. I had a lot of pain. The good news was no cancer detected in sentinel lymph node (I only had 1), the bad news was that they found 2 more IDC tumors on left for a total of three (all .7 to .8) and one DCIS .5 on right. I made the right choice in having a BMX. Now I am waiting for oncotype dx results as chemo may still be in my future. I had one drain pulled after one week and it wasn't that bad. I am hoping to get the other drain out today. It took a lot of courage for me to finally look at myself after I was able to unwrap the dressings, but I got through the shock of that too. I look a little lopsided and am very flat as PS was only able to fill 30 cc saline. I am trying to look at this process as one step at a time. Thinking of all of you this month...
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2013 03:45PM Piano-girl wrote: I just got a late Christmas present...my oncotype dx came back 13!  My BMX with TE was on dec 3...and the doc had to call the company today for the results.  No chemo for me.  My nerve zingers are also much better.  Have any of your PS suggested anything to lessen the scars? Hoping for more good new for all December Surgery sisters here...

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2013 02:40PM Piano-girl wrote: My scars have been covered with paper tape since the beginning, I just redo after showering. Went to PS yesterday and she suggested Scar Away silicon sheets so that's what I'm doing now. Had my first official fill since the initial 30 cc - she added a whopping 40 cc. Boy am I sore today. I just read about a local study where women with TE 's are being given Botox injections in chest muscle which really seems to help with discomfort. Wish I were a part of that study!

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2013 10:03AM Piano-girl wrote: It's interesting (and a little disconcerting ) that we are being told such different things...I was told not to lift my arms above my shoulders for 4 weeks post BMX. As a result my arm mobility is pathetic. I will be seeing a PT but was told each fill will lessen my flexibility - two steps forward and one step back?  I'm jealous of your mounds - I guess if you squint you might see some mounds on me-- PS filled a whopping 30 cc' s in me at initial surgery. I hate this iron bra feeling and my incisions still hurt, but they are so much better than those zingers. I found the zingers seemed to intensify with my activity level, so for a few days I walked as slow as an 80 year old woman.  I am off to PS today and she said we may do a fill. I want to get this process over with ASAP, but am also dreading more discomfort. Just have to keep my eye on the prize-- a long, healthy life!
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2014 01:03PM Piano-girl wrote: They say two steps forward, one step back...well I thought I was on the TE fill to exchange train until today.  I decided at the end of the year to change insurance as a result of the bc diagnosis (to give me more flexibility and choice).  I had been told by my previous breast surgeon AND oncologist no need for chemo (low oncotype score), no need for radiation ... etc.  I saw new PS who was very impressed with my scars (have to brag somewhere, right?) and I had second fill and am now at 120cc. (I am very small).  Went to new oncologist and the first thing she said was...looks like you may need radiation due to a very small margin (1mm) to skin. WHAT??!!!  Help!  Is anyone dealing with this?  I now have an appt. with a radiation oncologist and have put my reconstruction on hold until we have a plan.  So bummed.
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2014 06:09PM Piano-girl wrote: Momaton, just a guess, but you may be feeling nerve pain as your nerves start "waking up" after surgery.  Mine started at about 2 weeks or so after surgery and it was NOT FUN.  Mine felt like big electric zaps that would startle me into jumping sometimes.  I would be in tears and found myself walking around really slowly because any exertion seemed to make it worse.  I also felt like I had a really bad sunburn (but for me those zaps were worse).  I didn't find much helped except compression/massage.  I walked around holding myself for a good week.  The good news was that it really did get a lot better after a week or so.  The sunburned feeling lasted a few more weeks but now (at 8 weeks) all I have to deal with is these stupid rocks (TEs) on my chest!

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2014 12:35PM Piano-girl wrote: Dancermom: Sending good thoughts your way today! 1Mindyydnim: I had my BMX with TE one month ago and am doing just fine -- you will be too! A few more ideas: I bought 2 FOM pillows at Brookstone which have been great to use to sleep. My husband also got a 14 section (!) plastic pill box at the grocery store and when we got home from the hospital, he put labels over the tops with my med schedule for 24 hours. I was taking something 11 times each day at the beginning between pain meds, ibuprophen, muscle relaxants, stool softeners etc. He refilled each day. It made it a lot easier for me and gave him a job too!  You have made a brave, life SAVING decision...allow yourself to heal, take things very slowly, let others help you, be kind to yourself. You can do this!
Posts.Title: Mastectomy with reconstruction coming up....VERY NERVOUS 1MindyydniM1 Skiergirl

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2014 11:19PM Piano-girl wrote: Tomorrow will mark one year since my BMX (!) -- I wore Shimera cami's for 6 months straight.. They don't have a shelf bra (didn't need one plus I had IMF incisions), they are super soft and easy to step in and out of... They can be pricey, but I found all of mine at Nordstrom Rack anywhere between $6-11 each. LOVED THEM.

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2014 08:41PM Piano-girl wrote: I will chime in as a "silent one" on tamoxifen.  I've taken it since the beginning of Jan 2014.  I am 47 years old - no signs of menopause at the time.  I don't feel any different since being on it.  My periods have been as regular as clockwork ... in fact, the only thing I may have noticed was a slight decrease in appetite (but that may have been wishful thinking : ) ... no weight gain, bone pain, hot flashes - nothing out of the ordinary.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2014 11:42PM Piano-girl wrote: Bethq: I read a recent study that found the effectiveness of tamoxifen was improved with melatonin.  I talked with my Onc and she had read the study as well.  My onc said it certainly wouldn't hurt to try it so I have.  Though I wasn't having trouble sleeping on tamoxifen, the melatonin does knock me out -- so much so that I have cut the dose in half each night!  Might be worth a try!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2014 07:24PM Piano-girl wrote: I would like to share my story:  I am 47 years old with "extremely dense" breasts.  I had micro calcifications seen 7 years ago, biopsied and a clip placed to closely watch that area at each mammogram.  I had yearly mammograms (including 4/13) - all fine. Fastforward to Thanksgiving of this year: I felt a lump (same area), was told it was a cyst - but I insisted it be checked out. They sent me in for a 3D mammogram, then did ultrasound where they saw a suspicious area BEHIND the cyst.  Another biopsy: this time they found the cyst contained ADH cells, and the suspicious area was IDC .7cm.  I chose to do BMX 12/3 and before the surgery, I had an MRI with contrast on both sides.  NOTHING MORE WAS FOUND... After BMX, my final path report reported not one tumor of IDC (.7), but three!  All were clustered near first tumor but separate (the others were .8 and .7cm).  They also found .5cm of DCIS in other breast. I am thankful I chose to be aggressive.  Last week, I was at my local hospital and found a flyer talking about a new law passed in my state (Oregon) effective 1/1/14 -SB420. It states women must be told after a mammogram if they have "extremely dense breast tissue" as these women have DOUBLE the risk of breast cancer (similar to the risk of having a family history (mother, sister or daughter with cancer in one breast, after menopause). Extremely dense tissue is more than 75% dense tissue (not fat). Heterogeneously dense breasts are 51-75% dense tissue and can make it harder to see small tumors which means a "very slight added risk of breast cancer."  I don't want to scare people, but hopefully this information will help others in the process of making healthcare choices and in discussions with their surgeons etc...
Posts.Title: Extremely Dense breasts cinvee marie5890
